content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: its good to go

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun clash that can be solved in 5 minutes. I think Reverse mode might be a bit of a challenge, but with the digits given in the stub generator it shouldn't be much harder than Fastest or Shortest mode. Shortest mode will be very fun, I think.

I liked the crash, but I feel like it's too complex to resolve in the given time. I consider that it is not impossible to do (I don't think I can do it xD),Even so I approve. If you want the exercise to not be so complex, I recommend adding 2 spaces (one in front and one in the back) to the two points " : " in this way the input line would have a width of 15, making it easier to divide digits into a width of 3 characters.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple in comprehension, a little more complex in execution.

I like this clash. I personally was not able to finish in 5min, but believe it to be 100% possible. 

I took the approach of turning each number into a 9character string (ex. " _ | ||_|"), then switching for each digit. There's probs a more optimal way to do it, but I enjoyed the clash :).

This wouldn't be fun in Reverse because it's so hard to get your hands on the conversion table:

 _     _  _     _  _  _  _  _ 
| |  | _| _||_||_ |_   ||_||_|
|_|  ||_  _|  | _||_|  ||_| _|

Since you can't see the statement.
You could give it to clashers in the stub generator, but I think it's maybe just not an ideal reverse clash.

Solvable once you have that though, but trying to get the same benefit without it by grabbing digits from individual test cases and building up a table would be painful.

Goal
* Please show what each digit looks like, similar to what this clash does:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/21205ed14075ce77e88e8e922892f29b7117

Input
* Please mention "{{:}}".

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement, e.g. "write answer".

Thanks.

Done, thank you. I'm a bit uncomfortable with mentioning {{:}} in the input because it's actually two dot characters, not a colon character. But that's visible in the first test-case anyway, which is shown as example.
The first three visible tests contain all the digits 0 to 9, so it should not be that difficult to reconstruct in Reverse mode the conversion table you've mentioned?

I added the digit list in the stub generator.

The solution I wrote to publish the contribution didn't use this explicit conversion table at all, but indeed now that you mention it it's a possibility too:

def transpose(s):
    s = [*map(''.join,zip(*s))]
    return [''.join(s[i:i+3]) for i in range(0, len(s), 3)]

s = ''' _     _  _     _  _  _  _  _ 
| |  | _| _||_||_ |_   ||_||_|
|_|  ||_  _|  | _||_|  ||_| _|'''.splitlines()
s = transpose(s)
d = {x:k for k,x in enumerate(s)}

clock = [input() for _ in range(3)]
clock = [row[:6]+row[7:] for row in clock] # remove ':'
clock = transpose(clock)
H,h,M,m = (d[c] for c in clock)

print(f"{H}{h}:{M}{m}")
But to be honest I find this solution somewhat less fun. If you look at the solution at the bottom of the contribution you'll see I didn't use such an explicit table at all.

That's a nice, elegant way to solve it. :)

I think Fastest mode sometimes just incentivizes going for the most obvious solution, even when it's inelegant, because even if the elegant one takes a minute less to write up, it might take 2 minutes of extra thinking to come up with it. But I agree the table is less fun. Glad you've provided it to Reverse players now though.
Ah, sorry, my bad. Instead, please mention the two dots ({{.}}) in the middle form the colon in the clock display.
